Award.AwardTitle: Plasmonic devices for controlling light at the nanoscale

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to develop new plasmonic structures and devices for manipulating light and enhancing light-matter interactions at the nanoscale through the excitation of subwavelength plasmonic modes for device applications in sensing, switching, and photovoltaics.

The intellectual merit is to greatly advance the state of the art of nanoplasmonics by exploring nanoscale plasmonic structures and devices for enhancement of nonlinear optical effects, all-optical absorption switches, ultra-compact sensors, and plasmon-enhanced thin-film photovoltaic solar cells. The proposed research is potentially transformative, since the results of the program may lead to new opportunities for device applications, which will represent important breakthroughs in integrated optics, optical information processing, and renewable energy sources.

The broader impacts are fundamental breakthroughs in photonics science and engineering, a field which profoundly influences the quality of human life. This program will also provide excellent training opportunities for two graduate students. In addition, as part of the efforts on outreach and education, a new course on nanophotonics will be introduced in which numerical codes will be used to deepen the students? understanding of the basic physics of nanophotonic devices. Special focus will also be placed on incorporating undergraduate students into the research program, as well as on outreach to the local communities, and on recruiting minority graduate students to work on this program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The unique properties of surface plasmons enable light guiding and manipulation at the nanoscale. This could lead to miniaturized photonic circuits with length scales that are much smaller than those currently achieved. The newfound ability to use metallic nanostructures to manipulate light at nanometric length scales has opened a myriad of exciting opportunities. Plasmonics is being explored for its potential in subwavelength optics, data storage, light generation, lithography, microscopy, and biophotonics. The realization of plasmonic devices enables controlling light and enhancing light-matter interactions at the nanoscale - beyond the diffraction limit - something which is fundamentally impossible to achieve with dielectric-based device components. This in turn has profound implications for computing, communications, and energy applications. The development of these nanoscale devices and their integration is challenging. It is therefore important to undertake theoretical and computational studies in this area and to identify the most promising structures for specific device applications such as sensing, switching, and photovoltaics.

 

In this project we developed several new plasmonic structures and devices for manipulating light and enhancing light-matter interactions at the nanoscale through the excitation of subwavelength plasmonic modes for device applications in areas such as sensing, switching, and photovoltaics. We explored nanoscale plasmonic structures and devices such as all-optical absorption and magneto-optical switches, ultra-compact sensors, optical diodes, and highly directional emitters. In addition to the impact in the area of nanoplasmonics, our results could also have impact on other disciplines. For example, we introduced nanoscale plasmonic sensors enhanced by slow-light effects which could find applications in biosensing. We also introduced structures consisting of multiple optical microcavities at both the entrance and exit sides of a subwavelength plasmonic slit which could enhance the performance of near-field devices for data storage. Another example are the aperiodic highly directional narrowband infrared emitters that we designed which could have applications in gas detection schemes.

 

This program also provided training opportunities for several graduate students. In addition, as part of the efforts on outreach and education, we introduced a new course on nanophotonics in which numerical codes are used to deepen the students’ understanding of the basic physics of nanophotonic devices. We also incorporated several undergraduate students into the research program.
